By the second half of the 12th century, it is hard to find places that the =
Taira were not present. Descended from a grandson of Emperor Kammu, Takamoc=
hi (governor of Kazusa), by 1180, the Taira/Heike possessed 30 of the 66 pr=
ovinces through being zuryo, as well as possessing an alleged 500 shoen. Af=
ter the successful defeat of Sutoku (the Hogen no ran, 1156), and Fujiwara =
no Nobuyori (the Heiji no ran, 1159), Taira no Kiyomori sat at the head of =
a vast network of provinces and shoen, throughout Honshu, but primarily con=
centrated in the west. He was not like a later daimyo centred upon a partic=
ular province, although it is clear that he considered Fukuhara on the Inla=
nd Sea as his base (for both poltical and Song-Chinese trade control), atte=
mpting to permenantly move the capital there in the late 1170s), but domina=
ted positions and posts across the country; from regional officials, and es=
tate owners, to family members and vassals within the North Gate bushidan. =

M.Lorimer
